#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=By Joseph Conrad

#Text=Several of us , all more or less connected with the sea , were dining in a small river-hostelry not more than thirty miles from London , and less than twenty from that shallow and dangerous puddle to which our coasting men give the grandiose name of “ German Ocean . ”
#Text=And through the wide windows we had a view of the Thames ; an enfilading view down the Lower Hope Reach .
#Text=But the dinner was execrable , and all the feast was for the eyes .
#Text=That flavour of salt-water which for so many of us had been the very water of life permeated our talk .
#Text=He who hath known the bitterness of the Ocean shall have its taste forever in his mouth .
#Text=But one or two of us , pampered by the life of the land , complained of hunger .
#Text=It was impossible to swallow any of that stuff .
#Text=And indeed there was a strange mustiness in everything .

#Text=The wooden dining-room stuck out over the mud of the shore like a lacustrine dwelling ; the planks of the floor seemed rotten ; a decrepit old waiter tottered pathetically to and fro before an antediluvian and worm-eaten sideboard ; the chipped plates might have been disinterred from some kitchen midden near an inhabited lake ; and the chops recalled times more ancient still .

#Text=They brought forcibly to one ’s mind the night of ages when the primeval man , evolving the first rudiments of cookery from his dim consciousness , scorched lumps of flesh at a fire of sticks in the company of other good fellows ; then , gorged and happy , sat him back among the gnawed bones to tell his artless tales of experience -- the tales of hunger and hunt -- and of women , perhaps !
#Text=But luckily the wine happened to be as old as the waiter .
#Text=So , comparatively empty , but upon the whole fairly happy , we sat back and told our artless tales .
#Text=We talked of the sea and all its works .
#Text=The sea never changes , and its works for all the talk of men are wrapped in mystery .
#Text=But we agreed that the times were changed .
#Text=And we talked of old ships , of sea-accidents , of break-downs , dismastings ; and of a man who brought his ship safe to Liverpool all the way from the River Platte under a jury rudder .

#Text=We talked of wrecks , of short rations and of heroism -- or at least of what the newspapers would have called heroism at sea -- a manifestation of virtues quite different from the heroism of primitive times .
#Text=And now and then falling silent all together we gazed at the sights of the river .
#Text=A P. & O. boat passed bound down .
#Text=“ One gets jolly good dinners on board these ships , ” remarked one of our band .
#Text=A man with sharp eyes read out the name on her bows : Arcadia .
#Text=“ What a beautiful model of a ship ! ” murmured some of us .
#Text=She was followed by a small cargo steamer , and the flag they hauled down aboard while we were looking showed her to be a Norwegian .
#Text=She made an awful lot of smoke ; and before it had quite blown away , a high-sided , short , wooden barque , in ballast and towed by a paddle-tug , appeared in front of the windows .

#Text=All her hands were forward busy setting up the headgear ; and aft a woman in a red hood , quite alone with the man at the wheel , paced the length of the poop back and forth , with the grey wool of some knitting work in her hands .

#Text=“ German I should think , ” muttered one . “ The skipper has his wife on board , ” remarked another ; and the light of the crimson sunset all ablaze behind the London smoke , throwing a glow of Bengal light upon the barque ’s spars , faded away from the Hope Reach .

#Text=Then one of us , who had not spoken before , a man of over fifty , that had commanded ships for a quarter of a century , looking after the barque now gliding far away , all black on the lustre of the river , said :
#Text=This reminds me of an absurd episode in my life , now many years ago , when I got first the command of an iron barque , loading then in a certain Eastern seaport .
#Text=It was also the capital of an Eastern kingdom , lying up a river as might be London lies up this old Thames of ours .
#Text=No more need be said of the place ; for this sort of thing might have happened anywhere where there are ships , skippers , tugboats , and orphan nieces of indescribable splendour .
#Text=And the absurdity of the episode concerns only me , my enemy Falk , and my friend Hermann .

#Text=There seemed to be something like peculiar emphasis on the words “ My friend Hermann , ” which caused one of us ( for we had just been speaking of heroism at sea ) to say idly and nonchalantly :
#Text=“ And was this Hermann a hero ? ”
#Text=Not at all , said our grizzled friend .
#Text=No hero at all .
#Text=He was a Schiff-fuhrer : Ship-conductor .
#Text=That ’s how they call a Master Mariner in Germany .
#Text=I prefer our way .

#Text=The alliteration is good , and there is something in the nomenclature that gives to us as a body the sense of corporate existence : Apprentice , Mate , Master , in the ancient and honourable craft of the sea .

#Text=As to my friend Hermann , he might have been a consummate master of the honourable craft , but he was called officially Schiff-fuhrer , and had the simple , heavy appearance of a well-to-do farmer , combined with the good-natured shrewdness of a small shopkeeper .
#Text=With his shaven chin , round limbs , and heavy eyelids he did not look like a toiler , and even less like an adventurer of the sea .
#Text=Still , he toiled upon the seas , in his own way , much as a shopkeeper works behind his counter .
#Text=And his ship was the means by which he maintained his growing family .
